content.description: Maybe I stitched routes together, but this is the 2nd bolt line I saw when I got to Avalon and although it crosses Chastity, it climbs nicely and is the longest route of it's grade here for those collecting the whole set.
content.location: This shares the optional start for Chastity as described here on MP.  Just after the start down along the East/Right side of Avalon you'll see an obvious water streak.  Just left of that is a 4" gaping arch (Chastity's landmark); start below that.  Climb up left on a narrow sweeping ramp just left of that arch.  Continue passed a "charlie brown" tree and straight up the moat to the belay bolts on a tower.  (Arthurian prose?)

content.description: Follow the aforementioned weakness as it goes up and begins to curve rightward toward its end. Climb the face R of the curving section (crux) then more or less straight up on highly featured face another 20-30 feet. You can set a decent belay on slung natural features about 20-30 feet below the "top". To exit scramble up the obvious wide gully (5.easy) then walk back around the top and back down to the start using the approach trail to Avalon.
content.protection: Mid-size cam or two, small to medium tricams, slings for natural features.
content.location: The obvious weakness left of Black Knight with a small, shrubby oak growing out of the right-facing overlap/crack/corner/groove about 20 or so feet above the deck, and a large, hanging "dumpling" near the terminus of the O/C/C/G.

content.description:
Technical, thin face climbing down low, then more featured, but easier climbing up high.

 This route is not in STLIII. If anyone has information on it, please let me know.
content.location: The route immediately left of "Launcelot Deulake."

content.description: This climb is listed as "???? project" in Squeezing the Lemon III.  It's almost certain that Steve Johnson climbed this - see his post dated 10-29-12 in  this thread (ignore the rest of the thread, which is an argument about some other routes at Avalon).    At any rate it's a good climb revolving around a hard slab sequence in between the second and third bolt.  The start is a reachy 5.10 move, and after the crux is about 60 feet of much easier (5.8?) but enjoyable knob romping.
content.location: On the main Avalon wall, just to the left of "The Tourney Slot" and to the right of a distinctive water groove is an improbable looking slab.  This is the climb.

content.description: This is an excellent route with thoughtful sequences and a tricky crux move revolving around poor feet and cryptic pinches (or sidepulls? or crimps? Depends how you do it!).  While the 10c crux is short, the upper section features some very enjoyable, steep 9+ movement on perfect crystals.
content.location: Just as you drop down towards the main section of Avalon, you'll see a small alcove with some aspen trees at the base.  The Tourney Slot starts up into this alcove towards a steeper part of the wall.

content.description: Mostly very easy climbing leads up to a neat-o crux sequence just below the anchor.
content.protection: Quickdraws (10-12).  2 bolt anchor with lowering 'biners.  60M rope reaches fine.
content.location: On the far left side of the crag, to the right of a grungy corner.  This is the furthest left bolted climb on the cliff.

content.description: Good climbing on perfect rock.  A great warmup.
content.protection: Quickdraws (10-12ish).  2 bolt anchor with lowering 'biners.  If you spook easily, you could place a big cam in the crack formed by the two boulders at the base of the route.
content.location: This route is on the left side of the main wall at Avalon.  It starts up a pair of spooky looking boulders, just to the left of a distinctive smooth slab ("The Holy Grail 5.11").

content.description: A thin 5.7 slab move leads to interesting but easy climbing around a flake, then up another fun 5.7 undercling move to gain the anchor.
content.protection: If you don't mind running it out on 5.5/5.6, you can do it with just bolts (5 or so).  Or, bring a few cams - say a couple in the finger size and a #3/#4 for a flake.
content.location: On the far left side of Avalon, to the right of a grungy left-facing flake and a big evergreen leaning against the rock.

content.description: Caveat emptor:  No pro on this one, but Trad was the only option due to MP route type parameters.. Follow your nose up low-angle, slick, water sculpted shallow trough.
content.location: The obvious wide, black water stained trough on the far R end of Avalon.

content.description: Not my route, but some talented/confident folks put this up.  Although it's mostly bolts: it's trad. Spicy trad.  Slippery in a few spots even, it IS a water trough after all.   Good bolts though.
content.protection: 2 bolts to shared anchors (to the left).   Small cams/nuts possible in the horseshoe scallop down low.  Nothing after that but those bolts.
content.location: About 1/2 way down through the published routes in a shallow alcove.  The distinctive water groove w only 2 bolts will be obvious after seeing all the other well bolted routes.  Just right of Little Miss Treatment.

content.description: Slab to headwall.

A climb with a brief crux that includes a somewhat perplexing path and tough crimp cranking into a lieback crack. My partner broke a foothold on the crux which may have made it harder, but likely not by much.
content.location: This route is located just to the right of the Tourney slot in a bit of an alcove.

content.description: This is a very casual route with only maybe 1 or two moves at 6+/7 - the rest is 5.4-5.5.
content.location: On the far left side of Avalon, just to the right of Sword in the Stone. This is the second bolted line on the cliff.

content.description: Fun and reasonably sustained climb involving technical, slabby sequences with a short bulge move over a mini roof.
content.location: On the left side of Avalon is a small alcove with several routes, including the smooth slab of "The Holy Grail".  Maid Marian is to the right of these and starts up a curved, right facing corner and heads towards a small roof feature.

content.description: Can't believe this isn't in here.  Wow, what a classic 9!   One of the older routes here, predating Steve Johnson's work (he called it 5.8+).  Although it's mostly bolts, it climbs like old-style trad: cinch up your harness and tighten your shoes.  I called it PG-13 just to wake up the budding 5.9 leader.
content.protection: 3 bolts, a medium-large cam or two for that initial crack.   2-bolt anchor.
content.location: This is about 1/2 way down the published routes, starting on a good sized square flake behind a tree.  The rippled face above should be an obvious draw.  Just left of a remarkable water trough (Relic).

content.description: Another nice route.  Look left and see how they used to space bolts...
content.location: Next route down the hill from Lady of the Lake. This has perhaps the lowest 1st bolt so far.  If you get to the widely spaced bolts of Forged with Ancient Mental, you've gone too far.  The route passes just left of the thin horizontal scalloped arch which is ~20 feet up, and then straight up the headwall to anchors.

content.description: Up the left facing flake to slab, just right of Camelot II, the prominent right facing crack corner in the center of the fall.
content.protection: Bolts, with a couple pieces to protect the lower section. A #2, .4 Camelot or small medium nuts will do.

content.description: The 4th bolt line as you walk downhill at Avalon. Note: The first 2 bolted routes (Squire and Fife) share their 1st bolt start. This potentially creates some confusion if you're counting bolt lines in order to locate routes.
content.location: The 4th bolt line as you walk downhill at Avalon. The first two routes share a start, and Chastity begins lower down at a fallen log next to the cliff.

content.description: Use the boulder to establish yourself on the climb. The crux is at a short little steep section around the 4th and 5th bolts. The climbing eases up considerably after that.
content.protection: Bolts, shared bolted anchor with Green Lantren
content.location: Scramble up and start off the boulder next to Green Knight.

content.description: A few 11- slab moves lead to fun, mostly easy climbing up to the crux, a technical bulge encounter with mediocre sidepulls.
content.location: On the left side of the main Avalon wall is a very distinctive, smooth looking slab with 2 bolts.  This is the start of The Holy Grail.

content.description: Starts in a short dihedral section, then a cool 5.10 undercling crux is followed by easy climbing.  A strong 2.5 star climb.
content.location: On the left side of the main wall at Avalon, just to the left of a distinctive smooth slab ("The Holy Grail 5.11").

content.description: Climb over a couple of overlapping flakes then more or less straight up the face on knobs, plates, et. al. Makes a good way to exit the left end of Avalon. To exit from Avalon: From the top of the route (obvious), follow your nose up the wide low-angle gully that separates Avalon from Booker's Dome.
content.location: Left of Black Knight about 50'(?). Refer to photo(s).

content.description: TBD.
Very blank and vertical face down low, with significantly easier climbing after the first 30-40 feet.
content.protection: Bolts. The guidebook says it's R-rated.

content.description: If you start left of the black water streak, just below the sloping shelf, directly beneath the 4" gaping arch, you get a very different climb than listed in STLIII.  Try 5.3/.4   at a consistent grade, straight up to anchors: short and sweet.
content.protection: 4 bolts to a 2-bolt anchor next to the trail.  You could rap', lower or easily walk off.
content.location:
This was the first bolt line we found after starting down the trail on the right side of Avalon.  It goes through an obvious 4" arch, just left of a water streak.  (We didn't see or find any bolts at all for the first 2 routes listed in the new Squeezing The Lemmon III.) 

  As drawn in STLIII, drop down the trail another 15' and slab climb up right to the same 4 bolts... longer, slabbier, and harder.  Maybe some small pieces could provide protection in those cracks?  There is a log currently laying at this start.

content.description: Nice slab near the right side of the formation, before the trail gets steep and overgrown.  Climb up and tend right to a bolt, then place the optional cam, and more bolts above to the right.  I cut back left to the first set of anchors I saw which may not be the original line, but it lowered pretty straight down to the pack.  See the photo.
content.protection: 7 bolts to 2-bolt anchor and perhaps a .3/.4 cam for the overlap/arch.  2 more Quick Links would sure help the anchor.
content.location: This was the 3rd route I saw with bolts on the way down.  Best landmark is the little scallop arch/overlap. Currently a good size log at the belay.

content.description: Three bolts down low take you through a balancy/thin slab section to an obvious crack. The crack is a little flared and does not take pro overly well, but there may be some opportunities to sling some chicken heads. The climbing is very easy once you reach the predominant crack.
content.protection: 3 bolts, single rack, slings, bolted anchors.
content.location: Shares its start with Little Miss.

content.description: Follow the obvious crack L of "Sword in the Stone" up through a R facing corner to the anchors.
content.protection: SLCDs from 00 (Master Cam) to #4 (Camalot). Stoppers and tricams are useful, as well.

content.description: "Stout crux you spend time working out before committing to the moves." - EFR

Avalon is a great high elevation crag featuring some of the best rock quality on the mountain, a good variety of decent quality climbs, and a few gems.  It was mostly developed by the late Steve Johnson and friends around 2012. The routes at Avalon tend to be slab-oriented, with the occasional steep, cruxy bulge move.  You can get by with just quickdraws (12-15 or so), but a light rack opens up more good terrain. The rock is mostly south facing, so the routes get a lot of sun, but the base is shaded by some majestic evergreen trees so you can stay cool even on the hottest days of summer.  As usual, the best details are found in Squeezing the Lemmon III - only about half the routes are listed here.
